efore addressing it:
> 
> -What does it mean for a hidden node to "nothing =
more than 
duplicated 
> substrate input and/or output nodes?"  What is mea=
nt 
by "duplicate?"

 than that, what 
> else is there that is duplicated?


An a priori fabrica=
tion of the substrate, duplicate substrate input 
or output nodes, added as=
 substrate hidden nodes, for the purpose of 
effectively capturing input-to=
-input or output-to-input connections, 
due to the current limitation that =
1) nodes only have one unique 
input (i.e. the summation of multiple inputs=
 counts as only one 
unique input), and 2) an input has no activation funct=
ion (i.e. it 
just passes through the input value to its output.


> 
> -Wh=
at is an "input-to-input" or "output-to-input" connection?   In 
> general =
most ANN implementations do not allow connections to go 
into 
> inputs.  S=
o what does this mean?  And how does it relate to a 
hidden 
> node, which =
is neither an input nor an output?


Added substrate hidden nodes, for the =
purpose of effectively 
capturing input-to-input or output-to-input connect=
ions, due to the 
current limitation that 1) nodes only have one unique inp=
ut (i.e. the 
summation of multiple inputs counts as only one unique input)=
, and 2) 
an input has no activation function (i.e. it just passes through =
the 
input value to its output.

In other words, effectively moving an inpu=
t to a hidden node so as to 
enable the following: a) sumation of multiple =
inputs from other 
inputs and/or output nodes, and b) internal activation f=
unction.


> 
> -What is the "dimensionality of a node?"  A node exists in =
a space 
of 
> some number of dimensions, e.g. 2 or 3 dimensions.  Is that =
what 
you 
> mean?  Or do you mean the number of incoming or outgoing 
conn=
ections, 
> or something else?


1d, 2d, & 3d coordinates being a subset of=
 the total design space 
dimensionality. The dimensionality of an arbitrary=
 point "P" in 
design space, comprised of the following:
(a) problem specif=
ic inputs (PSIs);
(b) auxiliary additional parameters associated w/ PSIs;
(=
c) problem specific outputs (PSOs);
(d) auxiliary additional parameters ass=
ociated w/ PSOs;


> 
> -What is a "true" substrate hidden node?  I know yo=
u say it's "not 
a 
> computational dupe," but I don't know what that means=
 either.  A 
> computational duplicate in my understanding would be a node =
that 
has 
> the exact same weights on its incoming connections as some oth=
er 
> node.  But when would that ever be the case, and why is that not 
> a=
 "true" node even if it was the case?


A "true" hidden node in the substra=
te, does not maintain a rational 
basis of dimensionality.

A computational=
 dupe, or "pseudo" hidden node, is an a priori 
fabrication of the substrat=
e, duplicate substrate input or output 
nodes, added as substrate hidden no=
des, for the purpose of 
effectively capturing input-to-input or output-to-=
input connections, 
due to the current limitation that 1) nodes only have o=
ne unique 
input (i.e. the summation of multiple inputs counts as only one =

unique input), and 2) an input has no activation function (i.e. it 
just p=
asses through the input value to its output.

sionality?"  Again, I am not sure what you 
> mean by dimensionality with r=
espect to nodes?  Other than being at 
> some coordinate in the substrate, =
I don't know what dimensions 
there 
> are associated with the node?


1d, =
2d, & 3d coordinates being a subset of the total design space 
dimensionali=
ty. The dimensionality of an arbitrary point "P" in 
design space, comprise=
d of the following:
(a) problem specific inputs (PSIs);
(b) auxiliary addit=
ional parameters associated w/ PSIs;
(c) problem specific outputs (PSOs);
(=
d) auxiliary additional parameters associated w/ PSOs;


> 
> -What does th=
is mean: "a) nodes only have one unique input, and b) 
an 
> input has no a=
ctivation function?"  Nodes can have any arbitrary 
> number of inputs, so =
why do you say "one?"  Do you mean that all 
> inputs are summed before bei=
ng applied to the activation function? 


The summation of multiple inputs =
counts as only one unique input.

A normal input has no activation function=
 (i.e. it just passes 
through the input value to its output.

 
> That of =
course is how almost all ANNs work, so how does this 
question 
> apply spe=
cifically to HyperNEAT?  


I am attempting a more general statement that d=
oes not stop at 3d 
space and can handle the more general case of "true" hi=
dden nodes in 
the substrate, which do not maintain a rational basis of 
di=
mensionality.

"Questions:

r, how is the 
hypercube input topology reconciled?

 hypercube networks depending on if the 
current node (input or output), is=
 a substrate input, hidden or 
output node?
(3) How are substrate hidden no=
des handled when the hypercube is 
focused on the associated connecting sub=
strate weight? (variation 
on question 2)"

tanding, but I want to make sure I

he question.
